    • Method Detail

      • scaledZ

        public static Double scaledZ(double confidence_level,
                             double max_decisions)
        Calculates the scaled, two-sided "Z-value" for a given confidence level. For a normal distribution, the Z-value is the number of standard deviations from the mean corresponding to the given confidence level. A two-sided value distributes the confidence region equally around the mean of the distribution. The Z-value is scaled in order to account for multiple decision points throughout the experiment.
        Parameters:
        confidence_level - a value in the interval (0, 1); e.g. use 0.95 for 95%
        max_decisions - the number of 'independent' decision points that might occur, a reasonable value is 23
        Returns:
        scaled, two-sided Z-value

      • scaledZ

        public static Double scaledZ(double confidence_level)
        Calculates the scaled, two-sided "Z-value" for a given confidence level and the default number of decision points. For a normal distribution, the Z-value is the number of standard deviations from the mean corresponding to the given confidence level. A two-sided value distributes the confidence region equally around the mean of the distribution. The Z-value is scaled in order to account for multiple decision points throughout the experiment.
        Parameters:
        confidence_level - a value in the interval (0, 1); e.g. use 0.95 for 95%
        Returns:
        scaled, two-sided Z-value

      • calcMaxDecisions

        public static Double calcMaxDecisions(long min_impressions,
                                      long max_impressions)
        Calculates the scale factor to be used in adjusting for continuous monitoring of experiments. The scale factor can be thought of as the maximum number of 'independent' decision points that might exist during the course of an experiment.
        Parameters:
        min_impressions - the maximum number of unique impressions the experiment might have, suggestion: 10^10
        max_impressions - the minimum number of unique impressions before a decision might be made, suggestion: 100
        Returns:
        the scale factor, or number of 'independent' decision points
